segments.text: At half-past twelve next day, Lord Henry Wotton strolled from Curzon Street over to the Albany to call on his uncle, Lord Fermor – a genial if somewhat rough-mannered old bachelor. The world called him selfish because he derived no particular benefit from his existence, yet Society considered him generous, as he fed the people who amused him. (His background, his father’s capricious retirement from Madrid when not offered the Paris Embassy, and his own resignation from his father’s service all contributed to the development of his artful pursuit of doing nothing at all.)
segments.voice_traits: Calm, measured narration with clear pronunciation and a neutral British accent; deliberate pacing with thoughtful pauses to allow the listener to absorb the background details.

segments.text: Well, Harry, what brings you out so early? I thought you dandies never got up till two, and were not visible till five.

segments.text: Pure family affection, I assure you, Uncle George. I want to get something out of you.

segments.text: Money, I suppose. Well, sit down and tell me all about it. Young people, nowadays, imagine that money is everything.
segments.voice_traits: Dry humor with a slightly gravelly tone; moderate pace with subtle inflection to stress his irony regarding modern values.
segments.character_voice_traits: His voice is likely gruff and direct with the accents of an English gentleman of a bygone era. It is characterized by a hearty, blunt tone, frequently interspersed with sarcastic remarks and a wry sense of humor.

segments.text: Yes, and when they grow older they know it. But I don’t want money. It is only people who pay their bills who want that, Uncle George, and I never pay mine. Credit is the capital of a younger son, and one lives charmingly upon it. Besides, I always deal with Dartmoor’s tradesmen, and consequently they never bother me. What I want is information: not useful information, of course; useless information.
segments.voice_traits: Smooth and self-assured delivery with a playful lilt; precise enunciation and measured cadence, conveying a sense of mischief and detached amusement.
segments.character_voice_traits: Lord Henry's voice is likely deep, measured, and laced with a refined British accent, reflective of his upper-class background. He speaks with deliberate phrasing, often employing irony and delicate humor in his tone. His voice carries an air of relaxed authority and subtle seduction, perfectly complementing his habit of punctuating his speech with striking, memorable aphorisms.

segments.text: Well, I can tell you anything that is in an English Blue Book, Harry, although those fellows nowadays write a lot of nonsense. When I was in the Diplomatic, things were much better. But I hear they let them in now by examination. What can you expect? Examinations, sir, are pure humbug from beginning to end. If a man is a gentleman, he knows quite enough, and if he is not a gentleman, whatever he knows is bad for him.
segments.voice_traits: A reflective, somewhat grumbling tone with deliberate pauses; mild British inflection with a sense of exasperated reminiscence.
segments.character_voice_traits: His voice is likely gruff and direct with the accents of an English gentleman of a bygone era. It is characterized by a hearty, blunt tone, frequently interspersed with sarcastic remarks and a wry sense of humor.

segments.text: Mr. Dorian Gray does not belong to Blue Books, Uncle George.

segments.text: Mr. Dorian Gray? Who is he?
segments.voice_traits: A brisk inquiry in a tone of mild surprise, with a warm British accent and a short, clipped pace.
segments.character_voice_traits: His voice is likely gruff and direct with the accents of an English gentleman of a bygone era. It is characterized by a hearty, blunt tone, frequently interspersed with sarcastic remarks and a wry sense of humor.

segments.text: That is what I have come to learn, Uncle George. Or rather, I know who he is. He is the last Lord Kelso’s grandson. His mother was a Devereux, Lady Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about his mother. What was she like? Whom did she marry? You have known nearly everybody in your time, so you might have known her. I am very much interested in Mr. Gray at present. I have only just met him.
segments.voice_traits: Even and controlled tone with clear enunciation; a slight rising inflection on key details that underlines his curiosity, delivered at a moderate pace.
segments.character_voice_traits: Lord Henry's voice is likely deep, measured, and laced with a refined British accent, reflective of his upper-class background. He speaks with deliberate phrasing, often employing irony and delicate humor in his tone. segments.text: Kelso’s grandson! ... Of course... I knew his mother intimately. I believe I was at her christening. She was an extraordinarily beautiful girl, Margaret Devereux, and made all the men frantic by running away with a penniless young fellow – a mere nobody, sir, a subaltern in a foot regiment, or something of that kind. Certainly. I remember the whole thing as if it happened yesterday. The poor chap was killed in a duel at Spa a few months after the marriage. There was an ugly story about it. They said Kelso got some rascally adventurer, some Belgian brute, to insult his son-in-law in public – paid him, sir, to do it – and that the fellow spat on his man as if he had been a pigeon. The thing was hushed up, but, egad, Kelso ate his chop alone at the club for some time afterwards. He brought his daughter back with him, I was told, and she never spoke to him again. Oh, yes; it was a bad business. The girl died, too, within a year. So she left a son, did she? I had forgotten that. What sort of boy is he? If he is like his mother, he must be a good-looking chap.
segments.voice_traits: Animated storytelling with theatrical pauses; a rich, resonant tone and clear British enunciation. The voice swells with both amusement and a trace of bitter nostalgia.
segments.character_voice_traits: His voice is likely gruff and direct with the accents of an English gentleman of a bygone era. It is characterized by a hearty, blunt tone, frequently interspersed with sarcastic remarks and a wry sense of humor.

segments.text: He is very good-looking.
segments.voice_traits: Brief, succinct statement delivered with a confident, playful tone and a gentle smile in his vocal cadence.
segments.character_voice_traits: Lord Henry's voice is likely deep, measured, and laced with a refined British accent, reflective of his upper-class background. His voice carries an air of relaxed authority and subtle seduction, perfectly complementing his habit of punctuating his speech with striking, memorable aphorisms.

segments.text: I hope he will fall into proper hands. He should have a pot of money waiting for him if Kelso did the right thing by him. His mother had money, too – all the Selby property came to her through her grandfather. Her grandfather hated Kelso, thought him a mean dog. I recall he came to Madrid once when I was there. Egad, I was ashamed of him! The Queen used to ask me about the English noble who was always quarrelling with cabmen about their fares – they made quite a story of it. I didn’t dare show my face at Court for a month. I hope he treated his grandson better than he did the jarvies.
segments.voice_traits: Passionate, with a lively tempo and an animated rhythm; his voice carries a mix of nostalgic irritation and wry humor, punctuated by sudden changes in pitch and pace.
segments.character_voice_traits: His voice is likely gruff and direct with the accents of an English gentleman of a bygone era. It is characterized by a hearty, blunt tone, frequently interspersed with sarcastic remarks and a wry sense of humor.

segments.text: I don’t know. I fancy that the boy will be well off. He is not of age yet. He has Selby, I know – he told me so. And... his mother was very beautiful?
segments.voice_traits: Measured tone with a touch of inquisitiveness; smooth, clear enunciation and a subtle rising inflection on the concluding question.
segments.character_voice_traits: Lord Henry's voice is likely deep, measured, and laced with a refined British accent, reflective of his upper-class background. His voice carries an air of relaxed authority and subtle seduction, perfectly complementing his habit of punctuating his speech with striking, memorable aphorisms.

segments.text: Margaret Devereux was one of the loveliest creatures I ever saw, Harry. What on earth induced her to behave as she did, I never could understand. She could have married anybody she chose. Carlington was mad after her – he went on his knees and told me so himself. She laughed at him, and there wasn’t a girl in London at the time who wasn’t after him. And speaking of silly marriages, what is this humbug your father tells me about Dartmoor wanting to marry an American? Ain’t English girls good enough for him?
segments.voice_traits: Delivered in a lively, storytelling manner with a playful scoff; his accent is distinctly British with varied pacing that lends dramatic emphasis to his anecdotes.

segments.text: Thus was the crude tale of Dorian Gray’s parentage told. Creatures of tragic beauty, wild passion, and doomed romance were invoked—a beautiful woman risking everything for a mad passion, a few wild weeks of happiness cut short by treachery, and a child left to the cold tyranny of an old, loveless man. The tragic undertones added an almost modern romance to the lad. Behind every exquisite thing, there lurked a touch of sorrow—a secret tribute to beauty born of travails.

segments.text: Suddenly, Lord Henry stopped and glanced up at the houses. Realizing he had passed Aunt Agatha’s, he smiled to himself and turned back. Entering the sombre hall, a butler informed him that lunch had begun. He handed a hat and stick to a footman before proceeding into the dining-room.

segments.text: Lord Henry offered a facile excuse as he took the vacant seat beside his aunt. He surveyed the table: Dorian Gray bowed shyly from the end, a flush of pleasure lighting his cheeks; opposite sat the Duchess of Harley, a robust, kindly woman of ample presence; next to her, Sir Thomas Burdon, a Radical member of Parliament known for his droll culinary politics; seated to one side, Mr. Erskine of Treadley, a cultured old gentleman whose well-worn reserve was legendary; and nearby, Mrs. Vandeleur conversed earnestly with Lord Faudel, her counterpart in mediocrity.

segments.text: Was that a paradox? I did not think so. Perhaps it was. Well, the way of paradoxes is the way of truth. To test reality, we must see it on the tight rope. When the verities become acrobats, we can judge them.

segments.text: I can sympathize with everything except suffering. I simply cannot sympathize with that—it is too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. segments.text: I don’t desire to change anything in England except the weather. I am quite content with philosophic contemplation. But, as the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt through an over-expenditure of sympathy, I would suggest that we appeal to science to put us straight. segments.text: Yes, that is one of the great secrets of life. Nowadays most people die of a sort of creeping common sense, and discover when it is too late that the only things one never regrets are one’s mistakes.

segments.text: A ripple of laughter spread around the table. Lord Henry, riding the crest of his own witty improvisation, played with ideas; tossing them into the air, transforming them, letting them escape and recapturing them. segments.text: How annoying! I must go. I have to call for my husband at the club, take him to some absurd meeting at Willis’s Rooms where he is going to be in the chair. segments.text: I am too fond of reading books to care to write them, Mr. Erskine. I should like to write a novel, certainly—a novel that would be as lovely as a Persian carpet and as unreal. But there is no literary public in England for anything except newspapers, primers, and encyclopaedias. Of all people in the world, the English have the least sense of the beauty of literature.
